thread.title: Clean up continues after wild storms
thread.title_full: Clean up continues after wild storms

title: Clean up continues after wild storms
text:
Sydney storms: Clean up continues after wild weather rips through city The Daily Telegraph March 23, 2017 6:53am 
Thousands of homes in Sydney have had a night without power after a severe storm and damaging winds ripped through the city, bringing trees crashing down on power lines, houses and cars. 
And it’s likely those residents hit by the blackout in Mount Druitt, Castle Hill and Parramatta will remain without electricity until this afternoon with crews scrambling to clean-up and repair the damage caused by Wednesday afternoon’s storm. media_camera Trees have been blown over and power lines left on local streets around Whalan after a severe storm ravaged it's way through the area yesterday. Picture: Bill Hearne media_camera Homes in Western Sydney could be without power until this afternoon. Picture: Bill Hearne 
Western Sydney and the Hills District were the worst hit with lightning and strong winds cutting power to 33,000 properties at the peak of the storm on Wednesday. 
This morning 1,700 homes were still without power. 
Endeavour Energy was calling customers with registered life support equipment to check on their welfare. Rain totals from thunderstorms for #SydneyWeather on Wed. No storms expected today but more showers will develop. https://t.co/lnZQdONrwI pic.twitter.com/cTaf7Aq7Ju — BOM New South Wales (@BOM_NSW) March 22, 2017 
In Sydney’s north 800 homes in Berowra, 1300 in the Central Coast suburbs of Woy Woy and 400 in Saratoga were without power last night. Those residents were expected to have had their electricity restored by midnight, an Ausgrid spokeswoman told AAP. Large tree down at Mona Vale. One of 700+ jobs #NSWSES called to across #Sydney & #CentralCoast after #SevereThunderstorms pic.twitter.com/soOWCWsf1k — NSW SES (@NSWSES) March 22, 2017 
The State Emergency Service said crews were called to more than 700 homes across Sydney’s West as lightning struck Penrith, a howling gale almost tore tarpaulins from previously storm-damaged homes in Kellyville and Parramatta and Picton suffered through flash flooding. media_camera SSES crews clear fallen trees at Mt Druitt. Picture: Bob Barker. media_camera Trees down in Finisterre Ave, Whalan. Picture: Bob Barker. 
A SES spokesman said of those jobs, more than 200 were in the battered Mt Druitt area. 
Trains and flights were delayed, while commuters heading home experienced traffic chaos after trees fell onto power lines. media_camera Lightning striking Sydney as a storm rolled through on Wednesday afternoon media_camera Heavy storm clouds over Brisbane Water at Gosford on the NSW Central Coast. Picture: Troy Snook media_camera People at Mona Vale beach as a severe storm approaches yesterday. Picture: John Grainger 
But there won’t be a reprieve on Thursday with Sydney set to cop more showers, most likely in the morning and evening. There’s also a chance of a thunderstorm in the early morning.
